repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body: Specifying severity=nil will jump to the next diagnostic with the highest severity.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
--- See |diagnostic-severity|. Additionally, the value "auto" is supported which jumps to the next
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1158,8 +1186,9 @@ end
 --- (default: `true`)
 --- @field wrap? boolean
 ---
---- See |diagnostic-severity|.
---- @field severity vim.diagnostic.Severity
+--- See |diagnostic-severity|. Additionaly, the value "auto" is supported which jumps to the next

comment_data.body: Could `diagnostics[i - 1].severity` be lifted out of the loop as `local worst = diagnostics[1].severity`, to avoid the lookup on each item?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -813,11 +813,39 @@ local function next_diagnostic(position, search_forward, bufnr, opts, namespace)
   position[1] = position[1] - 1
   bufnr = get_bufnr(bufnr)
   local wrap = if_nil(opts.wrap, true)
-  local line_count = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
+
+  local auto_severity = opts.severity == 'auto'
+  if auto_severity then
+    -- Clear the severity filter so that we get all diagnostics
+    opts.severity = nil
+  end
+
   local diagnostics =
     get_diagnostics(bufnr, vim.tbl_extend('keep', opts, { namespace = namespace }), true)
+
+  -- When 'auto' severity is set, sort the diagnostics by severity. The first diagnostic then
+  -- contains the highest severity, and we can discard all diagnostics with a lower severity.
+  if auto_severity then
+    table.sort(diagnostics, function(a, b)
+      return a.severity < b.severity
+    end)
+
+    -- Find the first diagnostic where the severity does not match the highest severity, and remove
+    -- that element and all subsequent elements from the array
+    local len = #diagnostics
+    for i = 2, len do
+      if diagnostics[i].severity ~= diagnostics[i - 1].severity then

comment_data.body: Can we just document that severity=nil works like this, instead of introducing "auto" ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -813,11 +813,39 @@ local function next_diagnostic(position, search_forward, bufnr, opts, namespace)
   position[1] = position[1] - 1
   bufnr = get_bufnr(bufnr)
   local wrap = if_nil(opts.wrap, true)
-  local line_count = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
+
+  local auto_severity = opts.severity == 'auto'
+  if auto_severity then
+    -- Clear the severity filter so that we get all diagnostics
+    opts.severity = nil

comment_data.body:
It doesn't though, `severity=nil` means "get all diagnostics, regardless of severity". The `"auto"` value is only meaningful in the `goto` style functions, it has no meaning for the lower-level `get()` API.

`severity=nil` for the `goto` functions means "go to the next diagnostic, whatever it is".

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    local worst = (diagnostics[1] or {}).severity
```

I think otherwise this fails with no diagnostics

comment_data.body:
> `severity=nil` means "get all diagnostics, regardless of severity"

For goto_next/goto_prev specifically, that intuitively means what this PR is aiming for, right?

So it seems like a "plumbing" detail is being lifted into the public interface here. Internally, we might need to disambiguate something, but externally, goto_next(severity=nil) only means one reasonable thing...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -813,11 +813,39 @@ local function next_diagnostic(position, search_forward, bufnr, opts, namespace)
   position[1] = position[1] - 1
   bufnr = get_bufnr(bufnr)
   local wrap = if_nil(opts.wrap, true)
-  local line_count = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
+
+  local auto_severity = opts.severity == 'auto'
+  if auto_severity then
+    -- Clear the severity filter so that we get all diagnostics
+    opts.severity = nil

comment_data.body:
>why can't it mean "go to any next" for goto_next/goto_prev specifically?

That is what it means, I specified as such in my first comment.

>It seems like a "plumbing" detail is being lifted into the public interface here.

I disagree, this is an explicit change in behavior so belongs in the public interface. It only has semantic meaning when the ordering of diagnostics matters (as it does with the goto functions), which is why it doesn't make sense for e.g. `vim.diagnostic.get()`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -813,11 +813,39 @@ local function next_diagnostic(position, search_forward, bufnr, opts, namespace)
   position[1] = position[1] - 1
   bufnr = get_bufnr(bufnr)
   local wrap = if_nil(opts.wrap, true)
-  local line_count = api.nvim_buf_line_count(bufnr)
+
+  local auto_severity = opts.severity == 'auto'
+  if auto_severity then
+    -- Clear the severity filter so that we get all diagnostics
+    opts.severity = nil

comment_data.body:
> which is why it doesn't make sense for e.g. `vim.diagnostic.get()`.

I am not suggesting that get() learns "auto". I'm suggesting that goto_next changes its treatment of severity=nil. That "change in behavior" is not going to break anyone.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body:
>I'm suggesting that goto_next changes its treatment of severity=nil

But then how would someone use the current behavior (move to the next diagnostic in the buffer, regardless of severity)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body:
Do I understand this right, you're suggesting: 

- goto_next/prev default to worst severity (`severity = nil`, no new `auto`, to go to any next you'd have to set severity min/max)
- get/count remain unchanged. `severity = nil` implies all diagnostics

Sounds good to me, although the asymmetry between the methods bothers me a tiny bit I think it makes sense to have these default behaviours and I'd actually prefer that
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -813,11 +813,39 @@ local function next_diagnostic(position, search_forward, bufnr, opts, namespace)

+  if auto_severity then
+    -- Clear the severity filter so that we get all diagnostics
+    opts.severity = nil

comment_data.body:
> the asymmetry between the methods bothers me a tiny bit

yes, but maybe preferable to a special 'auto' string that isn't used anywhere else.

> how would someone use the current behavior (move to the next diagnostic in the buffer, regardless of severity)?

`:help diagnostic-severity` mentions a min/max or severity "range", but not sure if goto_xx() supports that yet?

comment_regular_data.body: I believe this should have been marked as breaking change, because behavior of `vim.diagnostic.goto_next()` and `vim.diagnostic.goto_prev()` (both without optional `vim.diagnostic.GotoOpts` argument) *did* change.

> have been marked as breaking change, because behavior of `vim.diagnostic.goto_next()` and `vim.diagnostic.goto_prev()` (both without optional `vim.diagnostic.GotoOpts` argument) _did_ change

Not all changes are breaking. what did this "break"? Going to some extra diagnostics doesn't "break" any scripts.

> Not all changes are breaking. what did this "break"? Going to some extra diagnostics doesn't "break" any scripts.

The opposite: now both of `goto_***()` functions may not go to *some* diagnostic entries (when used with allowed no arguments), no matter how much they try.

Yes, this does not make any script exit with error, only silently providing not intended behavior (which is arguably worse). If this is not considered "breaking", then OK. Is this explicitly documented in some linkable place in the help?

Im also beginning to doubt that this is a good idea to make this the default behavior. With the new default mappings, if I have 2 errors and a warning in a buffer, its not possible to select the warning *at all*. I suspect this will cause a lot of confusion and will be surprising to many users. 

IMO we either change the default mappings to navigate in order, or revert to using a special option to use the move to highest severity behavior.

> IMO we either change the default mappings to navigate in order, or revert to using a special option to use the move to highest severity behavior.

Only changing default mapping will still affect plugins which rely on `vim.diagnostic.goto_{next,prev}()`. So I'd prefer asking for a special option.

> So I'd prefer asking for a special option.

This is short-term thinking. We need to spend our energy building the best interface.

> Only changing default mapping will still affect plugins which rely on `vim.diagnostic.goto_{next,prev}()`. So I'd prefer asking for a special option.

Plugins can update their calls.

This is not a breaking change. Yes, sometimes the UI changes. 

No objection to updating the default mappings.

> Im also beginning to doubt that this is a good idea to make this the default behavior. With the new default mappings, if I have 2 errors and a warning in a buffer, its not possible to select the warning _at all_. I suspect this will cause a lot of confusion and will be surprising to many users.
> 
> IMO we either change the default mappings to navigate in order, or revert to using a special option to use the move to highest severity behavior.

Do you have an example case that explains why you'd want to move to the warning instead of the errors?


In my editing experience, warnings or hints are often a side effect of errors. E.g. a function is unused because the function calling it has a compile error.

Or another common scenario for me:
I update a function signature or type and have adapt all call-sites, some of files containing the call-sites have warnings, some of which cannot be addressed for whatever reason. There I want to jump from error to error, and skip the warnings.

>Do you have an example case that explains why you'd want to move to the warning instead of the errors?

It's the more the fact that it is not possible _at all_ to view the warnings so long as there are errors in the buffer that I find problematic. It strikes me as non-intuitive default behavior.

We could enhance `vim.diagnostic.setqflist()` and `vim.diagnostic.setloclist()` to list diagnostics in severity order so that `]q` and `[q` (or `]l` and `[l`) (https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/28525) navigate in severity order.

> This is short-term thinking. We need to spend our energy building the best interface.

Exactly, and the point here is that this new "auto" behaviour is not the best interface as default.

This new behaviour is dependent on all diagnostic providers agreeing on exactly what an error/warning/... are, and that makes this new method deeply flawed.

There was nothing wrong with the old default behaviour of these functions, so I would vote that we revert this and make it opt-in.

Although sorting by severity first does sound like a good compromise to me. I wouldn't mind this being the default, although there's good reason to leave it opt-in. In any case, this strikes me as a strictly more useful version (`autosort` instead of `autofilter`).

This would imply replacing `severity` with two new keys:
* `filter` (same behavior as `severity` filter from `getOpts`, with additional value `auto`)
* `sort` (either "none" or "severity")

These should be implemented for and passed through to `get`.

> > This is short-term thinking. We need to spend our energy building the best interface.
> 
> Exactly, and the point here is that this new "auto" behaviour is not the best interface as default.
> 
> This new behaviour is dependent on all diagnostic providers agreeing on exactly what an error/warning/... are, and that makes this new method deeply flawed.

That is an edge case. It can be solved by opting out, by passing a "min" filter?

"auto" seems like short-term thinking because it is a special case. Why can't the existing filters be used?

edit: see https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/28577#issuecomment-2084849480

> That is an edge case. It can be solved by opting out, by passing a "min" filter?

Having more than one diagnostic provider is certainly not an edge case.

> "auto" seems like short-term thinking because it is a special case. Why can't the existing filters be used?

It is special, and personally I don't think we need it at all. The compromise is providing it with an opt-in.

> Although sorting by severity first does sound like a good compromise to me. 

The current logic is able to be simple by only requiring to work on the highest level severity. Once you add the other severities with a more generic sorting approach, the logic will may get more complicated.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(diagnostic): support severity=nil for goto functions
